TITLE:
   Chief Complaint: back/jaw pain, nausea s/p cardiac cath with stent to
   LMCA
   24 Hour Events:
   Began coughing while in CCU and sat upright, was found to be bleeding
   from cath site and became nauseous and extremely agitated. Pressure
   held for 20 minutes. Given Zofran followed by Ativan 0.5 which did not
   calm pt. Pt continued to be restless, cough and bear down and cath site
   began bleeding again. Pressure held for 25 minutes, US negative for
   hematoma, Ativan 0.5 given. Pt began sundowning and Morphine 1mg IV was
   given. Increased bruising and induration developed along inguinal
   ligament and in suprapubic area. Hct dropped to 22.3 from 31.6 two days
   prior. 1UPRBC given and non contrast CT showed large pelvic hyperedense
   collection concerning for hematoma, measuring 10 x 7 cm. Fat stranding
   concerning for bleeding in the right thigh. Not able to comment on
   active extavazation.
   History obtained from [**Hospital 19**] Medical records
   Allergies:
   Codeine
   Nausea/Vomiting
   Scopolamine Hydrobromide
   AMS;
   Last dose of Antibiotics:
   Infusions:
   Other ICU medications:
   Morphine Sulfate - [**2111-9-19**] 12:15 AM
   Haloperidol (Haldol) - [**2111-9-19**] 03:25 AM

   Hydralazine - [**2111-9-19**] 04:30 AM

   Extremities: Right lower extremity edema: Absent, Left lower extremity

                             [**2111-9-19**]  04:53 AM

   212
   Other labs: CK / CKMB / Troponin-T:88//0.02, Differential-Neuts:89.6 %,
   Lymph:6.9 %, Mono:3.2 %, Eos:0.1 %, Ca++:8.5 mg/dL, Mg++:1.6 mg/dL,
   PO4:4.0 mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
   88yo F hx HTN, CKI, hypothyroidism, Sjogrens presented s/p cardiac cath
   with drug eluting stent to left main with extension to LAD.
   .
   # CORONARIES: Anginal equivalent is intrascapular back pain with
   nausea. Precath ECG showed ST elevations in V1-2 and AVR with
   depressions in 2,3,AVL. Left main disease seen on cath and stent placed
   to LMCA extending to LAD. Post-cath ECG essentially unchaged. Post-cath
   Tn 0.02 CK 88.
   - Aspirin 325 po qd
   - Plavix 75 po qd
   - Start Atorvastatin 80 po qd
   .
   # HEMATOMA: Developed as pt began sundowning and became very
   anxious/restless at around 8pm. Ultrasound was negative for hematoma,
   but induration and brusing along the inguinal ligament and suprapubic
   area developed afterwards. CT abd/pelvis showed 10x7cm pelvic fluid
   collection. Hct dropped from 31 two days PTA to 23. 2UPRBC given
 will
   check post transfusion H/H.
   - Contact interventionalist re: coiling procedure for involved vessels
   - Recheck H/H q6 to keep above [**8-24**]
   .
   # HYPERTENSION: On Atenolol at home. Hydralazine x1 last night.
   - On Amlodipine 5 po qd
   - Will increase Carvedilol to 12.5 po bid.
   .
   # PUMP: No previous caths or echos. No history or symptoms of previous
   HF. Pt appears euvolemic.
   - Obtain TTE today
   - Would increase Carvedilol to 12.5 po bid
   - Will hold off on ACE/[**Last Name (un) **] given rising creatinine as outpatient
   .
   # HYPOTHYROIDISM: TSH wnl two days PTA. Continue levothyroxine 88mcg po
   qd.
   .
   # CHRONIC KIDNEY INJURY: Baseline Cr 1yr ago was 1.3. Pt was advised to
   stop Olmesartan this past week over concerns of increased Cr to 2.0 two
   days PTA. Cr 1.7 on admission and 2.0 today with bump likely due to dye
   load. FENa 3.3 so prerenal component is unlikely. Urine Pr/Cr ratio 44
 spurious?
   - Hold nephrotoxins
   .
   # ANEMIA: Baseline outpatient H/H [**10-31**], MCV 93.
   - follow up pre-admission iron studies, B12, folate
   - Will continue to monitor ongoing blood loss and keep H/H above [**8-24**]
   .
   FEN: heart healthy low sodium diet. Kayexelate for increased potassium.
   .
   ACCESS: PIV's
   .
   PROPHYLAXIS:  -DVT ppx with pneumoboots.
   .
   CODE: Presumed full
   .
   COMM: patient, daughter is involved in care.
   .
   DISPO: CCU for now

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 88-year-old female with a history of hypertension, chronic kidney injury, hypothyroidism, and Sjogren's syndrome. She underwent cardiac catheterization with stenting to the left main coronary artery extending to the left anterior descending artery.

The patient has been experiencing back/jaw pain and nausea since the procedure. She began coughing while in the CCU and was found to be bleeding from the catheter site, which was managed with pressure and medication. She developed increased bruising and induration along the inguinal ligament and suprapubic area, and a non-contrast CT scan showed a large pelvic hyperedense collection concerning for hematoma, measuring 10 x 7 cm.

The patient's laboratory results show a decrease in hemoglobin (Hb) from 31.6 two days prior to 22.3, and a white blood cell count (WBC) of 10.6 K/uL. Her troponin-T level is 0.02 ng/mL, and her creatinine (Cr) level is 2.0 mg/dL.

The patient is currently being managed with medications for hypertension, chronic kidney injury, and hypothyroidism. She is also receiving anticoagulation therapy with aspirin, clopidogrel, and warfarin.

Potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's condition include:

1. Hematoma expansion: The patient's pelvic hematoma is concerning, and there is a risk of expansion, which could lead to bleeding, pain, and potentially life-threatening complications.
2. Bleeding: The patient has already experienced bleeding from the catheter site, which could recur, especially if the patient is not adequately anticoagulated.
3. Hypovolemic shock: The patient's decreased Hb level and increased bleeding risk could lead to hypovolemic shock, which requires prompt recognition and management.
4. Renal impairment: The patient's chronic kidney injury and rising Cr level could worsen, leading to further kidney damage and potentially life-threatening complications.
5. Anemia: The patient's decreased Hb level could worsen, leading to anemia, which could impact her overall health and quality of life.
6. Infection: The patient's indwelling catheters and potential bleeding could increase the risk of infection, which requires prompt recognition and management.
7. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's cardiac catheterization and stenting could lead to cardiovascular complications, such as arrhythmias, myocardial infarction, or cardiac tamponade.

In conclusion, the patient is at risk for various medical complications, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent and treat these complications.

   88yo F hx HTN, CKI, hypothyroidism, Sjogrens presented s/p cardiac cath
   with drug eluting stent to left main with extension to LAD.
   .
   # CORONARIES: Anginal equivalent is intrascapular back pain with
   nausea. Precath ECG showed ST elevations in V1-2 and AVR with
   depressions in 2,3,AVL. Left main disease seen on cath and stent placed
   to LMCA extending to LAD. Post-cath ECG essentially unchaged. Post-cath
   Tn 0.02 CK 88.
   - Aspirin 325 po qd
   - Plavix 75 po qd
   - Start Atorvastatin 80 po qd
   .
   # HEMATOMA: Developed as pt began sundowning and became very
   anxious/restless at around 8pm. Ultrasound was negative for hematoma,
   but induration and brusing along the inguinal ligament and suprapubic
   area developed afterwards. CT abd/pelvis showed 10x7cm pelvic fluid
   collection. Hct dropped from 31 two days PTA to 23. 2UPRBC given
 will
   check post transfusion H/H.
   - Contact interventionalist re: coiling procedure for involved vessels
   - Recheck H/H q6 to keep above [**8-24**]
   .
   # HYPERTENSION: On Atenolol at home. Hydralazine 10 IV x1 last night.
   - On Amlodipine 5 po qd
   - Will increase Carvedilol to 12.5 po bid.
   .
   # PUMP: No previous caths or echos. No history or symptoms of previous
   HF. Pt appears euvolemic.
   - Obtain TTE today
   - Would increase Carvedilol to 12.5 po bid
   - Will hold off on ACE/[**Last Name (un) **] given rising creatinine as outpatient
   .
   # HYPOTHYROIDISM: TSH wnl two days PTA. Continue levothyroxine 88mcg po
   qd.
   .
   # CHRONIC KIDNEY INJURY: Baseline Cr 1yr ago was 1.3. Pt was advised to
   stop Olmesartan this past week over concerns of increased Cr to 2.0 two
   days PTA. Cr 1.7 on admission and 2.0 today with bump likely due to dye
   load. FENa 3.3 so prerenal component is unlikely. Urine Pr/Cr ratio 44
 spurious?
   - Hold nephrotoxins
   .
   # ANEMIA: Baseline outpatient H/H [**10-31**], MCV 93.
   - follow up pre-admission iron studies, B12, folate
   - Will continue to monitor ongoing blood loss and keep H/H above [**8-24**]
   .
   FEN: heart healthy low sodium diet. Kayexelate for increased potassium.
   .
   ACCESS: PIV's
   .
   PROPHYLAXIS:  -DVT ppx with pneumoboots.
   .

   .

   .

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 88-year-old female who underwent cardiac catheterization with stenting to the left main coronary artery (LMCA) and left anterior descending (LAD) artery. She presented with back and jaw pain, nausea, and was found to be bleeding from the catheter site.

The patient developed a large pelvic hyperdense collection concerning for hematoma, measuring 10x7 cm, and fat stranding concerning for bleeding in the right thigh. Her hemoglobin dropped from 31.6 two days prior to 22.3, and she received 2 units of packed red blood cells.

The patient has a history of hypertension, chronic kidney injury, hypothyroidism, and Sjogren's syndrome. She is currently taking medications for hypertension, hypothyroidism, and chronic kidney injury.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 36.4°C (97.5°F), heart rate of 71 beats per minute, blood pressure of 182/78 mmHg, respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 97% on room air.

The patient's physical examination revealed a normocephalic head, clear oropharynx, bilateral carotid bruits, and a systolic ejection murmur heard best at the left upper sternal border. Her extremities showed no edema or cyanosis, but ecchymosis and induration were noted over the right inguinal ligament and suprapubic area.

The patient's laboratory results include a white blood cell count of 10.6 K/uL, hemoglobin of 22.3 g/dL, platelet count of 211 K/uL, creatinine of 2.0 mg/dL, and troponin-T of 0.02 ng/mL.

The patient's assessment and plan include:

1. Coronary artery disease: Aspirin 325 mg orally once a day, Plavix 75 mg orally once a day, and Atorvastatin 80 mg orally once a day.
2. Hematoma: Contact the interventionalist for a coiling procedure for involved vessels, and recheck hemoglobin every 6 hours to keep above 8-24 g/dL.
3. Hypertension: Increase Carvedilol to 12.5 mg orally twice a day, and hold off on ACE inhibitors given rising creatinine as an outpatient.
4. Pump failure: Obtain a transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) today, and increase Carvedilol to 12.5 mg orally twice a day.
5. Hypothyroidism: Continue levothyroxine 88 mcg orally once a day.
6. Chronic kidney injury: Hold nephrotoxins, and follow up pre-admission iron studies, B12, and folate.
7. Anemia: Follow up pre-admission iron studies, B12, and folate, and continue to monitor ongoing blood loss and keep hemoglobin above 8-24 g/dL.

Potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's condition include:

1. Hemorrhagic shock: Given the patient's bleeding from the catheter site and the development of a large pelvic hyperdense collection concerning for hematoma, there is a risk of hemorrhagic shock.
2. Renal failure: The patient's chronic kidney injury and rising creatinine levels increase the risk of renal failure.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient's coronary artery disease and pump failure increase the risk of cardiac complications such as myocardial infarction, heart failure, and arrhythmias.
4. Infection: The patient's indwelling catheters and medical devices increase the risk of infection.
5. Anemia: The patient's ongoing blood loss and anemia increase the risk of anemia and its complications.
6. Hypothyroidism: The patient's hypothyroidism increases the risk of hypothyroidism-related complications such as fatigue, cold intolerance, and weight gain.
7. Hypertension: The patient's hypertension increases the risk of hypertension-related complications such as cardiovascular disease, kidney disease, and stroke.

Based on the patient's condition and potential complications, it is essential to closely monitor her vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status, and to adjust her treatment plan accordingly.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 24-hour post-cardiac catheterization with stent placement in the left main coronary artery. The patient has experienced several concerning events, including bleeding from the catheter site, nausea, agitation, and restlessness. The patient's hemoglobin level has dropped significantly from 31.6 to 22.3, and a non-contrast CT scan revealed a large pelvic hyperdense collection measuring 10 x 7 cm, concerning for hematoma, and fat stranding in the right thigh, suggesting bleeding.

Potential medical complications that can arise from these events include:

1. Hemorrhagic shock: Given the significant bleeding and drop in hemoglobin levels, the patient is at risk of developing hemorrhagic shock, which can lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
2. Infection: The presence of a large pelvic hematoma and potential bleeding in the right thigh increases the risk of infection, which can spread to other parts of the body.
3. Organ damage: The bleeding and pressure from the hematoma can cause damage to surrounding organs, such as the bladder, ureters, and surrounding soft tissues.
4. Respiratory compromise: The patient's respiratory status is stable, but the presence of a large hematoma and potential bleeding in the right thigh can increase the risk of respiratory compromise.
5. Coagulopathy: The patient's decreased hemoglobin levels and potential bleeding can increase the risk of coagulopathy, which can lead to further bleeding complications.
6. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's cardiac catheterization and stent placement increase the risk of cardiovascular instability, which can be exacerbated by the bleeding and pressure from the hematoma.
7. Kidney injury: The patient's decreased hemoglobin levels and potential bleeding can increase the risk of kidney injury, which can lead to acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease.

Given these potential complications, it is essential to closely monitor the patient's vital signs, hemodynamic status, and laboratory results to ensure timely intervention and management of any developing complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 88-year-old female who underwent cardiac catheterization with stenting to the left main coronary artery and left anterior descending artery. The patient has a history of hypertension, chronic kidney injury, hypothyroidism, and Sjogren's syndrome.

The patient has developed several complications since admission, including:

1. Bleeding from the catheter site, which required pressure holding and the administration of Zofran and Ativan.
2. Hematoma formation in the pelvic region, which was detected on non-contrast CT scan and is measuring 10 x 7 cm.
3. Anemia, with a hemoglobin level of 22.3 g/dL, which is a decrease from the previous level of 31.6 g/dL.
4. Increased bruising and induration along the inguinal ligament and suprapubic area.
5. Sundowning, which required the administration of Morphine.
6. Respiratory support, including oxygen therapy and nasal cannula.
7. Cardiovascular issues, including a systolic crescendo decrescendo murmur heard best at the left upper sternal border.

The patient is currently being treated with several medications, including aspirin, Plavix, atorvastatin, carvedilol, amlodipine, and hydralazine. The patient is also receiving prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis with pneumatic boots.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Hemorrhagic shock due to continued bleeding from the catheter site.
2. Respiratory failure due to worsening anemia or pulmonary edema.
3. Cardiac arrhythmias due to the administration of Morphine or other medications.
4. Infection or sepsis due to the presence of a pelvic hematoma.
5. Renal failure due to continued nephrotoxicity or prerenal azotemia.
6. Hypothyroidism or hyperthyroidism due to changes in thyroid hormone levels.
7. Anemia or bleeding disorders due to ongoing blood loss or platelet dysfunction.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment accordingly to prevent or manage these potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 88-year-old female who underwent cardiac catheterization with stenting of the left main coronary artery and extension to the left anterior descending (LAD) artery. She developed back/jaw pain, nausea, and bleeding from the catheter site, which was managed with pressure holding and medication. However, the bleeding continued, and a non-contrast computed tomography (CT) scan revealed a large pelvic hyperdense collection concerning for a hematoma, measuring 10x7 cm.

The patient's vital signs are stable, but she has developed signs of delirium, including sundowning, agitation, and restlessness. She has also developed ecchymosis and induration along the inguinal ligament and suprapubic area, which may be related to the pelvic hematoma.

The patient has a history of hypertension, chronic kidney injury, hypothyroidism, and Sjogren's syndrome. She is currently taking multiple medications, including aspirin, Plavix, Atorvastatin, Atenolol, Amlodipine, and Carvedilol.

The potential medical complications that can arise from these conditions include:

1. Hematoma expansion and bleeding: The patient's pelvic hematoma is large and may continue to expand, leading to further bleeding and potentially life-threatening complications.
2. Renal failure: The patient's chronic kidney injury and rising creatinine levels increase the risk of acute kidney injury or further decline in renal function.
3. Hypothyroidism: The patient's hypothyroidism may worsen if not adequately managed, leading to symptoms such as fatigue, weight gain, and cold intolerance.
4. Delirium: The patient's delirium may worsen if not managed appropriately, leading to increased agitation, restlessness, and potential harm to herself or others.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen if not managed with adequate blood transfusions and iron supplementation, leading to fatigue, shortness of breath, and decreased cognitive function.
6. Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiac catheterization and stenting may have caused cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias, heart failure, or cardiac tamponade.

Based on the patient's condition, the plan of care should focus on managing her bleeding, delirium, and other medical complications. This may involve adjusting her medication regimen, providing supportive care, and consulting with specialists such as nephrology, cardiology, and urology.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 88-year-old female who underwent cardiac catheterization with stenting to the left main coronary artery and extension to the left anterior descending artery. She presented with back/jaw pain, nausea, and was found to be bleeding from the catheter site. The patient's hemoglobin dropped from 31.6 to 22.3, and a non-contrast CT scan showed a large pelvic hyperdense collection concerning for a hematoma, measuring 10 x 7 cm.

The patient developed symptoms of delirium, sundowning, and anxiety, which worsened after being given benzodiazepines. She was treated with Ativan and Haldol, but continued to be restless and agitated. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.4°C, heart rate of 71 bpm, and blood pressure of 182/78 mmHg.

The patient has a history of hypertension, chronic kidney injury, hypothyroidism, and Sjogren's syndrome. She is being treated with aspirin, Plavix, and Atorvastatin, and has a medication list that includes Atenolol, Amlodipine, Carvedilol, and Levothyroxine.

Potential medical complications that can arise from this situation include:

1. Hemorrhagic shock: The patient's hemoglobin dropped significantly, and she is at risk of developing hemorrhagic shock if not treated promptly.
2. Renal failure: The patient has a history of chronic kidney injury, and the contrast dye used during the cardiac catheterization may have further exacerbated this condition.
3. Hyponatremia: The patient's sodium levels are not mentioned in the note, but she is at risk of developing hyponatremia due to the use of diuretics and the presence of a large pelvic hematoma.
4. Electrolyte imbalances: The patient's potassium levels are not mentioned in the note, but she is at risk of developing electrolyte imbalances due to the use of diuretics and the presence of a large pelvic hematoma.
5. Infection: The patient's wound is at risk of infection due to the presence of a large pelvic hematoma and the use of invasive procedures.
6. Respiratory failure: The patient's oxygen saturation is stable, but she is at risk of developing respiratory failure due to the presence of a large pelvic hematoma and the use of diuretics.
7. Cardiac complications: The patient has a history of cardiac disease and is at risk of developing cardiac complications such as arrhythmias, heart failure, or myocardial infarction.

The patient should be closely monitored for any signs of these complications and treated promptly if they arise.

   Assessment and Plan
   88yo F hx HTN, CKI, hypothyroidism, Sjogrens presented s/p cardiac cath
   with drug eluting stent to left main with extension to LAD.
   .
   # CORONARIES: Anginal equivalent is intrascapular back pain with
   nausea. Precath ECG showed ST elevations in V1-2 and AVR with
   depressions in 2,3,AVL. Left main disease seen on cath and stent placed
   to LMCA extending to LAD. Post-cath ECG essentially unchaged. Post-cath
   Tn 0.02 CK 88.  No anginal equivalent since admission to CCU.
   - Aspirin 325 po qd
   - Plavix 75 po qd
   - Atorvastatin 80 po qd
   .
   # HEMATOMA: Developed as pt began sundowning and became very
   anxious/restless at around 8pm. Ultrasound was negative for hematoma,
   but induration and brusing along the inguinal ligament and suprapubic
   area developed afterwards. CT abd/pelvis showed 10x7cm pelvic fluid
   collection. Hct dropped from 31 two days PTA to 23. 2UPRBC given
 will
   check post transfusion H/H. Hematoma also possibly compressing R ureter
   causing hydronephrosis and possible calyceal rupture.
   - Contact vascular re: coiling procedure for involved vessels or
   evacuation -> no intervention indicated
   - Consult urology re: possible calyceal rupture -> recommended
   conservative management at this point
   - Recheck H/H q6 to keep above [**8-24**] -> transfused one unit PRBC
   overnight, will transfuse another unit this AM
   .
   # DELIRIUM: History of sundowning on previous hospital admissions.
   Given benzos last night and mental status deteriorated.  Pulled out
   some IVs and foley catheter. Will continue treating underlying
   conditions. Would stay away from benzos and use Haldol or Seroquel /
   Trazodone qpm. Use restraints as needed.
   - no recurrence overnight
   .
   # HYPERTENSION: On Atenolol at home. Hydralazine 10 IV previously
   required, none overnight.
   - Amlodipine 5 po qd
   - Carvedilol 6.25 po bid
   .
   # PUMP: No previous caths or echos. No history or symptoms of previous
   HF. Pt appears euvolemic.  However, was given volume and has diastolic
   dysfunction
 will stop IV fluids and give lasix prior to next unit
   blood.
   - TTE -> see above, preserved LVEF > 55%
   - On Carvedilol 6.25 po bid
   - Will hold off on ACE/[**Last Name (un) **] given rising creatinine as outpatient ->
   will start when renal function improves
   .
   # HYPOTHYROIDISM: TSH wnl two days PTA. Continue levothyroxine 88mcg po
   qd.
   .
   # CHRONIC KIDNEY INJURY: Baseline Cr 1yr ago was 1.3. Pt was advised to
   stop Olmesartan this past week over concerns of increased Cr to 2.0 two
   days PTA. Cr 1.7 on admission and 2.0 today with bump likely due to dye
   load. FENa 3.3 so prerenal component is unlikely.  SCr cont to rise
   slowly.  Pt likely had significant CKD at baseline, given small body
   habitus
   - Hold nephrotoxins, given gentle IVF, monitor SCr
   .
   # ANEMIA: Baseline outpatient H/H [**10-31**], MCV 93.
   - follow up pre-admission iron studies, B12, folate
   - Will continue to monitor ongoing blood loss and keep H/H above [**8-24**]
   -> post Tx Hct showed
   .
   FEN: heart healthy low sodium diet. Kayexelate for increased potassium
   given overnight
   .
   ACCESS: PIV's
   .
   CODE: Presumed full
   .
   COMM: patient, daughter is involved in care.
   .
   DISPO: CCU for now

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 88-year-old female with a history of hypertension, chronic kidney injury, hypothyroidism, and Sjogren's syndrome, who presented with left main disease and underwent a cardiac catheterization with a drug-eluting stent placement to the left main coronary artery extending to the left anterior descending artery.

The patient's current condition is complicated by the development of a large pelvic hematoma, which is compressing the right ureter and causing hydronephrosis and possible calyceal rupture. The patient has also experienced sundowning and anxiety, which has led to the removal of IVs and the foley catheter.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

1. Continued bleeding from the pelvic hematoma, which can lead to further compression of the right ureter and worsening of hydronephrosis.
2. Infection of the pelvic hematoma, which can lead to sepsis and organ failure.
3. Delayed healing of the pelvic hematoma, which can lead to chronic pain and disability.
4. Chronic kidney injury, which can worsen the patient's underlying kidney disease and increase the risk of end-stage renal disease.
5. Hypothyroidism, which can worsen the patient's underlying condition and increase the risk of complications such as heart failure and osteoporosis.
6. Sjogren's syndrome, which can worsen the patient's underlying condition and increase the risk of complications such as dry mouth, dry eyes, and joint pain.

The patient's treatment plan should focus on managing the pelvic hematoma, addressing the patient's underlying conditions, and preventing complications. This may include:

1. Monitoring the patient's hematoma size and location to prevent further compression of the right ureter.
2. Providing antibiotics to prevent infection of the pelvic hematoma.
3. Administering pain medication to manage the patient's pain and discomfort.
4. Managing the patient's underlying conditions, such as hypertension, chronic kidney injury, and hypothyroidism.
5. Providing education and support to the patient and her family to help manage her condition and prevent complications.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent complications and improve her quality of life.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 88-year-old female with a history of hypertension, coronary artery disease, hypothyroidism, and Sjogren's syndrome. She was admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of left main disease and underwent cardiac catheterization with a drug-eluting stent placement to the left main coronary artery extending to the left anterior descending artery.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.3°C, heart rate of 65 beats per minute, blood pressure of 130/50 mmHg, respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96%. Her physical examination is remarkable for a large extraperitoneal hematoma in the right pelvis, which is compressing the right distal ureter and causing hydronephrosis and possible calyceal rupture. Her abdominal examination is soft, with bowel sounds present, and tender in the lower quadrants, right greater than left.

The patient's laboratory results show a hemoglobin level of 24.2%, platelet count of 211,000/μL, and creatinine level of 2.0 mg/dL. Her troponin T level is 0.02 ng/mL, and her CK-MB level is 88 U/L.

The patient's medical conditions and complications include:

1. Left main disease with stent placement
2. Large extraperitoneal hematoma in the right pelvis
3. Compressive hydronephrosis and possible calyceal rupture
4. Hypertension
5. Hypothyroidism
6. Chronic kidney injury with rising creatinine levels
7. Anemia
8. Possible chronic kidney disease at baseline

The patient's potential medical complications include:

1. Bleeding complications from the large hematoma
2. Chronic kidney disease progression
3. Hypertensive crisis
4. Thyroid crisis
5. Anemia worsening
6. Respiratory failure
7. Cardiac complications from the left main disease
8. Infection

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Conservative management of the hematoma and hydronephrosis
2. Transfusion of blood products as needed to maintain a hemoglobin level above 8-24%
3. Monitoring of creatinine levels and holding nephrotoxins if necessary
4. Management of hypertension with medications
5. Treatment of hypothyroidism with levothyroxine
6. Monitoring of anemia and possible iron deficiency
7. Cardiac monitoring and management of left main disease
8. Infection prevention and control measures

The patient's disposition is to remain in the ICU for now, with further evaluation and management planned as needed.

Summary:

The patient is a 60-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of left main disease. He has been receiving conservative management for acute coronary syndrome (ACS), acute renal failure (ARF), and retroperitoneal bleed (RP bleed). His vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.3°C, heart rate of 65 bpm, and blood pressure of 130/50 mmHg. He is receiving maintenance IV fluids and has received two units of packed red blood cells. His lab results show a hemoglobin level of 24.2%, platelet count of 211 K/uL, and creatinine level of 2.7 mg/dL.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Progressive ARF: The patient's creatinine level is increasing, indicating worsening renal function. This may lead to further fluid overload, electrolyte imbalances, and acidosis.
2. Coronary Ischemia: The patient's ACS is not fully resolved, and he may be at risk for further coronary ischemia or infarction.
3. Sepsis: The patient has a central line and is at risk for central line-associated bloodstream infection (CLABSI).
4. Delirium: The patient has a history of delirium and is at risk for further episodes, particularly with ongoing sedation and pain management.
5. Hemorrhage: The patient has a retroperitoneal bleed and is at risk for further bleeding, particularly with anticoagulation therapy.
6. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is low, and he may be at risk for bleeding or thrombosis.
7. Hyperkalemia: The patient's potassium level is elevated, and he may be at risk for cardiac arrhythmias or other complications.
8. Hypoglycemia: The patient's glucose level is low, and he may be at risk for hypoglycemic episodes, particularly with ongoing insulin therapy.
9. Fluid Overload: The patient is receiving large amounts of IV fluids, and he may be at risk for fluid overload, particularly with ongoing cardiac and renal dysfunction.

Recommendations:

1. Continue conservative management for ACS and ARF.
2. Monitor the patient's vital signs and lab results closely for signs of worsening ARF, coronary ischemia, or sepsis.
3. Consider consulting cardiology and nephrology services for further management.
4. Implement strategies to prevent CLABSI, such as changing the central line every 3-7 days.
5. Monitor the patient's mental status and consider consulting psychiatry services for further management of delirium.
6. Monitor the patient's bleeding risk and consider consulting hematology services for further management.
7. Monitor the patient's potassium and glucose levels closely and adjust therapy as needed.
8. Consider consulting nutrition services for further management of the patient's nutritional needs.

   Assessment and Plan
   88yo F hx HTN, CKI, hypothyroidism, Sjogrens presented s/p cardiac cath
   with drug eluting stent to left main with extension to LAD.
   .
   # CORONARIES: Anginal equivalent is intrascapular back pain with
   nausea. Precath ECG showed ST elevations in V1-2 and AVR with
   depressions in 2,3,AVL. Left main disease seen on cath and stent placed
   to LMCA extending to LAD. Post-cath ECG essentially unchaged. Post-cath
   Tn 0.02 CK 88.  No anginal equivalent since admission to CCU.
   - Aspirin 325 po qd
   - Plavix 75 po qd
   - Atorvastatin 80 po qd
   .
   # HEMATOMA: Developed as pt began sundowning and became very
   anxious/restless at around 8pm. Ultrasound was negative for hematoma,
   but induration and brusing along the inguinal ligament and suprapubic
   area developed afterwards. CT abd/pelvis showed 10x7cm pelvic fluid
   collection. Hct dropped from 31 two days PTA to 23. 2UPRBC given
 will
   check post transfusion H/H. Hematoma also possibly compressing R ureter
   causing hydronephrosis and possible calyceal rupture.
   - Contact vascular re: coiling procedure for involved vessels or
   evacuation -> no intervention indicated
   - Consult urology re: possible calyceal rupture -> recommended
   conservative management at this point
   - Recheck H/H q6 to keep above [**8-24**] -> transfused one unit PRBC
   overnight
   .
   # DELIRIUM: History of sundowning on previous hospital admissions.
   Given benzos last night and mental status deteriorated.  Pulled out
   some IVs and foley catheter. Will continue treating underlying
   conditions. Would stay away from benzos and use Haldol or Seroquel /
   Trazodone qpm. Use restraints as needed.
   - no recurrence overnight
   .
   # HYPERTENSION: On Atenolol at home. Hydralazine 10 IV previously
   required, none overnight.
   - Amlodipine 5 po qd
   - Carvedilol 6.25 po bid
   .
   # PUMP: No previous caths or echos. No history or symptoms of previous
   HF. Pt appears euvolemic.
   - TTE -> see above, preserved LVEF
   - On Carvedilol 6.25 po bid
   - Will hold off on ACE/[**Last Name (un) **] given rising creatinine as outpatient ->
   will start when renal function improves
   .
   # HYPOTHYROIDISM: TSH wnl two days PTA. Continue levothyroxine 88mcg po
   qd.
   .
   # CHRONIC KIDNEY INJURY: Baseline Cr 1yr ago was 1.3. Pt was advised to
   stop Olmesartan this past week over concerns of increased Cr to 2.0 two
   days PTA. Cr 1.7 on admission and 2.0 today with bump likely due to dye
   load. FENa 3.3 so prerenal component is unlikely.  SCr cont to rise
   slowly.  Pt likely had significant CKD at baseline, given small body
   habitus
   - Hold nephrotoxins, given gentle IVF, monitor SCr
   .
   # ANEMIA: Baseline outpatient H/H [**10-31**], MCV 93.
   - follow up pre-admission iron studies, B12, folate
   - Will continue to monitor ongoing blood loss and keep H/H above [**8-24**]
   -> post Tx Hct showed
   .
   FEN: heart healthy low sodium diet. Kayexelate for increased potassium
   given overnight
   .
   ACCESS: PIV's
   .
   CODE: Presumed full
   .
   COMM: patient, daughter is involved in care.
   .
   DISPO: CCU for now

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's current condition as follows:

* The patient is a 88-year-old female with a history of hypertension, coronary artery disease, and hypothyroidism, who was admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of left main disease and underwent a cardiac catheterization with stenting.
* The patient has developed a large extraperitoneal hematoma in the right pelvis, which is compressing the right ureter and causing hydronephrosis and possible calyceal rupture.
* The patient's hemoglobin has dropped from 31 to 23, and they have received two units of packed red blood cells (PRBCs).
* The patient has been experiencing anxiety and restlessness, which has led to sundowning, and has had difficulty sleeping.
* The patient has a history of delirium and has been treated with benzodiazepines, which has led to worsening of their mental status.
* The patient has been experiencing hypertension, which has been managed with antihypertensive medications.
* The patient has chronic kidney injury (CKI) and has a rising serum creatinine (SCr) level, which is likely due to the dye load from the cardiac catheterization.
* The patient has anemia and is being monitored for ongoing blood loss.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

* Further bleeding from the pelvic hematoma, which could lead to hypovolemic shock and organ failure.
* Ureteral obstruction and hydronephrosis, which could lead to kidney damage and potentially life-threatening complications.
* Delirium and anxiety, which could worsen the patient's mental status and lead to further complications.
* Hypertension, which could lead to further organ damage and potentially life-threatening complications.
* Chronic kidney injury, which could lead to further worsening of the patient's kidney function and potentially life-threatening complications.
* Anemia, which could lead to further worsening of the patient's hemodynamic status and potentially life-threatening complications.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential complications, I recommend the following:

* Continue to monitor the patient's hemodynamic status and vital signs closely.
* Monitor the patient's blood loss and transfusion requirements closely.
* Continue to manage the patient's hypertension and chronic kidney injury with antihypertensive medications and close monitoring of SCr levels.
* Consider consulting with a nephrologist to further manage the patient's chronic kidney injury.
* Consider consulting with a urologist to further manage the patient's pelvic hematoma and ureteral obstruction.
* Continue to monitor the patient's mental status and provide close monitoring and treatment for delirium and anxiety.
* Consider consulting with a palliative care specialist to further manage the patient's symptoms and improve their quality of life.

   Assessment and Plan
   88yo F hx HTN, CKI, hypothyroidism, Sjogrens presented s/p cardiac cath
   with drug eluting stent to left main with extension to LAD.
   .
   # CORONARIES: Anginal equivalent is intrascapular back pain with
   nausea. Precath ECG showed ST elevations in V1-2 and AVR with
   depressions in 2,3,AVL. Left main disease seen on cath and stent placed
   to LMCA extending to LAD. Post-cath ECG essentially unchaged. Post-cath
   Tn 0.02 CK 88.  No anginal equivalent since admission to CCU.
   - Aspirin 325 po qd
   - Plavix 75 po qd
   - Atorvastatin 80 po qd
   .
   # HEMATOMA: Developed as pt began sundowning and became very
   anxious/restless at around 8pm. Ultrasound was negative for hematoma,
   but induration and brusing along the inguinal ligament and suprapubic
   area developed afterwards. CT abd/pelvis showed 10x7cm pelvic fluid
   collection. Hct dropped from 31 two days PTA to 23. 2UPRBC given
 will
   check post transfusion H/H. Hematoma also possibly compressing R ureter
   causing hydronephrosis and possible calyceal rupture.
   - Contact vascular re: coiling procedure for involved vessels or
   evacuation -> no intervention indicated
   - Consult urology re: possible calyceal rupture -> recommended
   conservative management at this point
   - Recheck H/H q6 to keep above [**8-24**] -> transfused one unit PRBC
   overnight
   .
   # DELIRIUM: History of sundowning on previous hospital admissions.
   Given benzos last night and mental status deteriorated.  Pulled out
   some IVs and foley catheter. Will continue treating underlying
   conditions. Would stay away from benzos and use Haldol or Seroquel /
   Trazodone qpm. Use restraints as needed.
   - no recurrence overnight
   .
   # HYPERTENSION: On Atenolol at home. Hydralazine 10 IV previously
   required, none overnight.
   - Amlodipine 5 po qd
   - Carvedilol 6.25 po bid
   .
   # PUMP: No previous caths or echos. No history or symptoms of previous
   HF. Pt appears euvolemic.
   - TTE -> see above, preserved LVEF > 55%
   - On Carvedilol 6.25 po bid
   - Will hold off on ACE/[**Last Name (un) **] given rising creatinine as outpatient ->
   will start when renal function improves
   .
   # HYPOTHYROIDISM: TSH wnl two days PTA. Continue levothyroxine 88mcg po
   qd.
   .
   # CHRONIC KIDNEY INJURY: Baseline Cr 1yr ago was 1.3. Pt was advised to
   stop Olmesartan this past week over concerns of increased Cr to 2.0 two
   days PTA. Cr 1.7 on admission and 2.0 today with bump likely due to dye
   load. FENa 3.3 so prerenal component is unlikely.  SCr cont to rise
   slowly.  Pt likely had significant CKD at baseline, given small body
   habitus
   - Hold nephrotoxins, given gentle IVF, monitor SCr
   .
   # ANEMIA: Baseline outpatient H/H [**10-31**], MCV 93.
   - follow up pre-admission iron studies, B12, folate
   - Will continue to monitor ongoing blood loss and keep H/H above [**8-24**]
   -> post Tx Hct showed
   .
   FEN: heart healthy low sodium diet. Kayexelate for increased potassium
   given overnight
   .
   ACCESS: PIV's
   .
   CODE: Presumed full
   .
   COMM: patient, daughter is involved in care.
   .
   DISPO: CCU for now

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 88-year-old female who presented with left main disease and underwent cardiac catheterization with a drug-eluting stent placement to the left main coronary artery extending to the left anterior descending artery. She has a history of hypertension, chronic kidney injury, hypothyroidism, and Sjogren's syndrome.

The patient's current condition is stable, with no acute distress. She is receiving maintenance IV fluids, and her hemoglobin level has been increasing after transfusions. Her blood pressure is under control, and she is on a heart-healthy low-sodium diet.

However, the patient has developed a large pelvic hematoma, which is compressing her right ureter, causing hydronephrosis and possible calyceal rupture. She also has a small atrophic left kidney.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated creatinine levels, indicating chronic kidney injury. Her potassium levels are slightly elevated, and she is receiving kayexelate to manage this.

The patient's cardiac function is preserved, with a left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) greater than 55%. She is on beta-blockers and is being monitored for any signs of heart failure.

The patient's anemia is being managed with ongoing blood transfusions, and her iron studies, B12, and folate levels will be followed up.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Further bleeding from the pelvic hematoma, which could lead to hypovolemic shock.
2. Chronic kidney injury progressing to end-stage renal disease.
3. Development of heart failure due to underlying left main disease.
4. Increased risk of infection due to immunosuppression.
5. Nutritional deficiencies due to chronic kidney injury and anemia.

The patient's treatment plan includes continued management of her left main disease, monitoring of her blood pressure, and management of her chronic kidney injury. She will also be followed up for any signs of heart failure, and her anemia will be managed with ongoing blood transfusions and nutritional supplements.

   Assessment and Plan
   88yo F hx HTN, CKI, hypothyroidism, Sjogrens presented s/p cardiac cath
   with drug eluting stent to left main with extension to LAD.
   .
   # CORONARIES: Anginal equivalent is intrascapular back pain with
   nausea. Precath ECG showed ST elevations in V1-2 and AVR with
   depressions in 2,3,AVL. Left main disease seen on cath and stent placed
   to LMCA extending to LAD. Post-cath ECG essentially unchaged. Post-cath
   Tn 0.02 CK 88.
   - Aspirin 325 po qd
   - Plavix 75 po qd
   - Start Atorvastatin 80 po qd
   .
   # HEMATOMA: Developed as pt began sundowning and became very
   anxious/restless at around 8pm. Ultrasound was negative for hematoma,
   but induration and brusing along the inguinal ligament and suprapubic
   area developed afterwards. CT abd/pelvis showed 10x7cm pelvic fluid
   collection. Hct dropped from 31 two days PTA to 23. 2UPRBC given
 will
   check post transfusion H/H. Hematoma also possibly compressing R ureter
   causing hydronephrosis and possible calyceal rupture.
   - Contact vascular re: coiling procedure for involved vessels or
   evacuation
   - Consult urology re: possible calyceal rupture
   - Recheck H/H q6 to keep above [**8-24**]
   .
   # DELIRIUM: History of sundowning on previous hospital admissions.
   Given benzos last night and mental status deteriorated.  Pulled out
   some IVs and foley catheter. Will continue treating underlying
   conditions. Would stay away from benzos and use Haldol or Seroquel /
   Trazodone qpm. Use restraints as needed.
   .
   # HYPERTENSION: On Atenolol at home. Hydralazine 10 IV x1 last night.
   - On Amlodipine 5 po qd
   - On Carvedilol 6.25 po bid
   .
   # PUMP: No previous caths or echos. No history or symptoms of previous
   HF. Pt appears euvolemic.
   - Obtain TTE today
   - On Carvedilol 6.25 po bid

   .
   # HYPOTHYROIDISM: TSH wnl two days PTA. Continue levothyroxine 88mcg po
   qd.
   .
   # CHRONIC KIDNEY INJURY: Baseline Cr 1yr ago was 1.3. Pt was advised to
   stop Olmesartan this past week over concerns of increased Cr to 2.0 two
   days PTA. Cr 1.7 on admission and 2.0 today with bump likely due to dye
   load. FENa 3.3 so prerenal component is unlikely.
   - Hold nephrotoxins
   .
   # ANEMIA: Baseline outpatient H/H [**10-31**], MCV 93.

Summary:

The patient is an 88-year-old female with a history of hypertension, coronary artery disease, and hypothyroidism, who presented with symptoms of intrascapular back pain with nausea and was diagnosed with left main disease and stent placement to the left main coronary artery extending to the left anterior descending artery. She has developed a hematoma in the right groin area, which may be compressing the right ureter and causing hydronephrosis and possible calyceal rupture. She has also experienced delirium and sundowning, and has been treated with benzodiazepines, which have been discontinued due to mental status deterioration.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Hematoma expansion: The hematoma in the right groin area may continue to expand and compress the right ureter, causing further hydronephrosis and possible calyceal rupture.
2. Renal impairment: The patient's creatinine levels have increased, and she has a history of chronic kidney injury. Further decline in renal function may occur if the hematoma is not managed promptly.
3. Hypothyroidism: The patient's thyroid function has not been adequately monitored, and hypothyroidism may exacerbate her underlying conditions.
4. Delirium: The patient's delirium may worsen if her underlying conditions are not managed effectively, and may lead to further complications such as falls or respiratory depression.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen if her ongoing blood loss is not managed effectively, and may lead to further complications such as cardiovascular instability.
6. Infection: The patient's indwelling catheter and central lines may increase her risk of infection, which may be exacerbated by her immunocompromised state.
7. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's underlying coronary artery disease and stent placement may increase her risk of cardiovascular instability, which may be exacerbated by her anemia and hypothyroidism.

Recommendations:

1. Manage the hematoma promptly to prevent further expansion and compression of the right ureter.
2. Monitor the patient's renal function closely and adjust her treatment plan accordingly.
3. Monitor the patient's thyroid function closely and adjust her thyroid medication as needed.
4. Manage the patient's delirium effectively using non-pharmacological interventions and medication as needed.
5. Monitor the patient's anemia closely and adjust her treatment plan accordingly.
6. Implement infection prevention measures to reduce the risk of infection.
7. Monitor the patient's cardiovascular stability closely and adjust her treatment plan accordingly.

   88yo F hx HTN, CKI, hypothyroidism, Sjogrens presented s/p cardiac cath
   with drug eluting stent to left main with extension to LAD now with
   pelvic hematoma and renal caliceal rupture.
   .
   # CORONARIES: Anginal equivalent is intrascapular back pain with
   nausea. Precath ECG showed ST elevations in V1-2 and AVR with
   depressions in 2,3,AVL. Left main disease seen on cath and stent placed
   to LMCA extending to LAD. Post-cath ECG essentially unchaged. Post-cath
   Tn 0.02 CK 88.  No anginal equivalent since admission to CCU.
   - Aspirin 325 po qd
   - Plavix 75 po qd

   .

   anxious/restless ~2hrs s/p cath. Ultrasound was negative for hematoma,
   but induration and brusing along the inguinal ligament and suprapubic
   area developed afterwards. CT abd/pelvis showed 10x7cm pelvic fluid
   collection. Hematoma also possibly compressing R ureter causing
   hydronephrosis and possible calyceal rupture. Hct dropped from 31 two
   days PTA to 23.
   - Vascular on board
 no intervention indicated
   - Urology on board
 recommended conservative management at this point
   - Hct stable from last night
 will recheck H/H q12 to keep above [**8-24**]
 4UPRBC so far
   .

   Given benzos last night and mental status deteriorated.  Pulled out
   some IVs and foley catheter. Will continue treating underlying
   conditions. Would stay away from benzos and use Haldol or Seroquel /
   Trazodone qpm. Use restraints as needed.
   - no recurrence overnight
   .
   # HYPERTENSION: On Atenolol at home. Hydralazine 10 IV previously
   required, none overnight.
   - Amlodipine 5 po qd
   - Carvedilol 6.25 po bid

   HF. Pt appears euvolemic. Echo showed mild diastolic dysfunction but
   EF>55%. Will hold off on fluid boluses

   yesterday.
   - On Carvedilol 6.25 po bid
   - Will hold off on ACE/[**Last Name (un) **] given rising creatinine as outpatient ->
   will start when renal function improves
   .
   # CHRONIC KIDNEY INJURY: Baseline Cr 1yr ago was 1.3. Pt was advised to
   stop Olmesartan this past week over concerns of increased Cr to 2.0 two
   days PTA. Cr 1.7 on admission. GFR likely significantly low at baseline
   given age and small body habitus. FENa 3.3 so prerenal component is
   unlikely. SCr continues to rise slowly post-cath likely [**2-2**] dye load.
   - Hold nephrotoxins
   - Scr stable for past 24hrs
 will continue to monitor
   - Can d/c Foley
   .
   # HYPOTHYROIDISM: TSH wnl two days PTA. Continue levothyroxine 88mcg po
   qd.
   .
   # ANEMIA: Baseline outpatient H/H [**10-31**], MCV 93. Anemia of chronic
   disease on iron studies.
   - Will continue to monitor ongoing blood loss and keep H/H above [**8-24**]
   .
   FEN: heart healthy low sodium diet. Would add Zofran prn for nausea.
   .

   .

Based on the patient's progress note, the following summary can be made:

The patient is an 88-year-old female who underwent cardiac catheterization with a drug-eluting stent placement to the left main coronary artery extending to the left anterior descending (LAD) artery. She developed a pelvic hematoma and renal caliceal rupture post-procedure. She is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) with ongoing monitoring and treatment.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.1°C, heart rate of 67 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 119/61 mmHg. Her oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. She has a mild confusion and is attempting to pull out her Foley catheter, which is being managed by the staff.

The patient's laboratory results show a rising creatinine level, with a current value of 3.1 mg/dL. Her hemoglobin level is stable, and her platelet count is normal. Her white blood cell count is slightly elevated.

The patient has a history of hypertension, chronic kidney injury, and hypothyroidism. She is currently taking several medications, including aspirin, Plavix, atorvastatin, amlodipine, carvedilol, and levothyroxine.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Worsening of the pelvic hematoma, which could lead to further bleeding and potentially life-threatening complications.
2. Continued rise in creatinine levels, which could indicate worsening kidney function and potentially require further intervention.
3. Development of acute kidney injury (AKI) or chronic kidney disease (CKD) due to the combination of underlying kidney disease, hypovolemia, and nephrotoxic medications.
4. Hematuria and hydronephrosis due to the pelvic hematoma and potential ureteral compression.
5. Nausea and vomiting, which could lead to dehydration and electrolyte imbalances.
6. Delirium, which could worsen with continued use of sedatives and potentially lead to further complications.
7. Hypothyroidism, which could worsen with continued use of sedatives and potentially lead to further complications.

The patient's management plan should focus on closely monitoring her vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status. She should continue to receive treatment for her pelvic hematoma, and her medications should be adjusted as needed to manage her blood pressure, kidney function, and thyroid function.

Summary:

The patient is an 88-year-old female who underwent a cardiac catheterization with stenting to the left main coronary artery extending to the left anterior descending (LAD) artery. She presented with pelvic hematuria and renal caliceal rupture. She has a history of hypertension, chronic kidney injury, hypothyroidism, and Sjogren's syndrome. She was given 1 unit of packed red blood cells (PRBCs) and Lasix 80 overnight. Her creatinine trend is 2.7 -> 3.1 -> 3.1, and her hemoglobin (Hb) level is stable.

The patient has mild confusion, attempts to pull out her Foley catheter, and has mild musculoskeletal back pain, lower abdominal pain, and nausea. She is aware that she is not mentally herself while in the hospital. She denies symptoms of shortness of breath, headache, lightheadedness, vomiting, constipation/diarrhea, and dysuria.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.6°C, heart rate of 67 beats per minute, blood pressure of 119/61 mmHg, respiratory rate of 21 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96%. Her physical examination is unremarkable, except for mild edema in the right lower extremity.

Laboratory results show an increase in creatinine from 2.0 to 3.1, and a decrease in hemoglobin from 32.5% to 25.1%. Other laboratory results, including white blood cell count, platelet count, and troponin-T, are within normal limits.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient has several medical conditions, including hypertension, chronic kidney injury, hypothyroidism, and Sjogren's syndrome. She has developed pelvic hematuria and renal caliceal rupture following cardiac catheterization. Her creatinine level is increasing, and her hemoglobin level is stable.

The patient's plan includes:

* Aspirin 325 mg orally once daily
* Plavix 75 mg orally once daily
* Atorvastatin 80 mg orally once daily
* Amlodipine 5 mg orally once daily
* Carvedilol 6.25 mg orally twice daily
* Levothyroxine 88 mcg orally once daily
* Hold nephrotoxins and continue to monitor creatinine level
* Continue to monitor ongoing blood loss and keep hemoglobin level above 8-24
* Prescribe Zofran prn for nausea

   Assessment and Plan
   88yo F hx HTN, CKI, hypothyroidism, Sjogrens presented s/p cardiac cath
   with drug eluting stent to left main with extension to LAD now with
   pelvic hematuria and renal caliceal rupture.
   .
   # CORONARIES: Anginal equivalent is intrascapular back pain with
   nausea. Precath ECG showed ST elevations in V1-2 and AVR with
   depressions in 2,3,AVL. Left main disease seen on cath and stent placed
   to LMCA extending to LAD. Post-cath ECG essentially unchaged. Post-cath
   Tn 0.02 CK 88.  No anginal equivalent since admission to CCU.
   - Aspirin 325 po qd
   - Plavix 75 po qd
   - Atorvastatin 80 po qd
   .
   # HEMATOMA: Developed as pt began sundowning and became very
   anxious/restless ~2hrs s/p cath. Ultrasound was negative for hematoma,
   but induration and brusing along the inguinal ligament and suprapubic
   area developed afterwards. CT abd/pelvis showed 10x7cm pelvic fluid
   collection. Hematoma also possibly compressing R ureter causing
   hydronephrosis and possible calyceal rupture. Hct dropped from 31 two
   days PTA to 23.
   - Vascular on board
 no intervention indicated
   - Urology on board
 recommended conservative management at this point
   - Recheck H/H q6 to keep above [**8-24**]
 4UPRBC so far
   .
   # DELIRIUM: History of sundowning on previous hospital admissions.
   Given benzos last night and mental status deteriorated.  Pulled out
   some IVs and foley catheter. Will continue treating underlying
   conditions. Would stay away from benzos and use Haldol or Seroquel /
   Trazodone qpm. Use restraints as needed.
   - no recurrence overnight
   .
   # HYPERTENSION: On Atenolol at home. Hydralazine 10 IV previously
   required, none overnight.
   - Amlodipine 5 po qd
   - Carvedilol 6.25 po bid
   .
   # PUMP: No previous caths or echos. No history or symptoms of previous
   HF. Pt appears euvolemic. Echo showed diastolic dysfunction but EF>55%.
   Will hold off on fluid boluses
 got Lasix 80 prior to PRBC yesterday.
   - On Carvedilol 6.25 po bid
   - Will hold off on ACE/[**Last Name (un) **] given rising creatinine as outpatient ->
   will start when renal function improves
   .
   # HYPOTHYROIDISM: TSH wnl two days PTA. Continue levothyroxine 88mcg po
   qd.
   .
   # CHRONIC KIDNEY INJURY: Baseline Cr 1yr ago was 1.3. Pt was advised to
   stop Olmesartan this past week over concerns of increased Cr to 2.0 two
   days PTA. Cr 1.7 on admission and 2.0 today with bump likely due to dye
   load. FENa 3.3 so prerenal component is unlikely.  SCr cont to rise
   slowly.  Pt likely had significant CKD at baseline, given small body
   habitus
   - Hold nephrotoxins, given gentle IVF, monitor SCr
   .
   # ANEMIA: Baseline outpatient H/H [**10-31**], MCV 93. Anemia of chronic
   disease on iron studies.
   - Will continue to monitor ongoing blood loss and keep H/H above [**8-24**]
   -> post Tx Hct showed
   .
   FEN: heart healthy low sodium diet. Kayexelate for increased potassium
   given overnight
   .
   ACCESS: PIV's
   .
   CODE: Presumed full
   .
   COMM: patient, daughter is involved in care.
   .
   DISPO: CCU for now

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 88-year-old female with a history of hypertension, chronic kidney injury, hypothyroidism, and Sjogren's syndrome. She was admitted to the ICU after undergoing a cardiac catheterization with a drug-eluting stent placement to the left main coronary artery extending to the left anterior descending artery.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.6°C, heart rate of 67 beats per minute, blood pressure of 119/61 mmHg, respiratory rate of 21 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96%. Her physical examination is notable for a well-nourished appearance, no acute distress, and anxiety.

The patient has developed several medical complications, including:

1. Pelvic hematuria and renal caliceal rupture, which are likely related to the cardiac catheterization.
2. Hematoma, which developed after the procedure and is compressing the right ureter, causing hydronephrosis and possible calyceal rupture.
3. Anemia, which is being managed with blood transfusions.
4. Delirium, which has been treated with benzodiazepines but has worsened.
5. Hypertension, which is being managed with medications.
6. Chronic kidney injury, which is being monitored closely.

The patient is receiving several medications, including aspirin, clopidogrel, atorvastatin, and hydralazine, as well as fluids and electrolyte replacement therapy.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Sepsis or septic shock due to the pelvic hematoma or urinary tract infection.
2. Acute kidney injury or worsening chronic kidney disease due to the continued rise in creatinine levels.
3. Heart failure or cardiac arrhythmias due to the patient's underlying cardiac disease.
4. Respiratory complications, such as pneumonia or acute respiratory distress syndrome, due to the patient's underlying lung disease.
5. Gastrointestinal bleeding or perforation due to the patient's history of bleeding disorders.
6. Neurological complications, such as stroke or seizures, due to the patient's underlying cardiovascular disease.

In conclusion, the patient is at high risk for developing several medical complications, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent or treat these complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual in the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) with multiple complex medical conditions.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.1°C (98.7°F), heart rate of 67 bpm, and blood pressure of 119/61 mmHg. The patient's respiratory rate is 21 inspirations per minute, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air.

The patient's cardiac status is of concern, with a diagnosis of acute coronary syndrome (ACS), unstable angina, and coronary ischemia. The patient has received 1 unit of packed red blood cells and has been treated with ranitidine.

The patient's renal function is compromised, with a creatinine level of 3.1 mg/dL and a blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level of 27 mg/dL. The patient has received furosemide (Lasix) for fluid management.

The patient's neurological status is also concerning, with a diagnosis of delirium and confusion. The patient's mental status has not been formally assessed, and the patient is unable to follow commands.

The patient has a history of hypertension and chest pain, which may be contributing factors to their current medical conditions.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's conditions include:

1. Cardiac complications: The patient's ACS, unstable angina, and coronary ischemia increase the risk of cardiac arrest, myocardial infarction, and cardiac arrhythmias.
2. Renal complications: The patient's acute renal failure (ARF) increases the risk of further kidney damage, electrolyte imbalances, and fluid overload.
3. Neurological complications: The patient's delirium and confusion may progress to seizures, coma, or even death if left untreated.
4. Infection: The patient's compromised immune system and prolonged hospitalization increase the risk of nosocomial infections, including sepsis and pneumonia.
5. Bleeding complications: The patient's retroperitoneal bleed (RP bleed) may worsen if not managed promptly, leading to hemorrhagic shock and potential death.

It is essential to continue monitoring the patient's vital signs, cardiac status, renal function, and neurological status closely to prevent or manage these potential complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   88yo F hx HTN, CKI, hypothyroidism, Sjogrens presented s/p cardiac cath
   with drug eluting stent to left main with extension to LAD now with
   pelvic hematoma and renal caliceal rupture.
   .
   # CORONARIES: Anginal equivalent is intrascapular back pain with
   nausea. Precath ECG showed ST elevations in V1-2 and AVR with
   depressions in 2,3,AVL. Left main disease seen on cath and stent placed
   to LMCA extending to LAD. Post-cath ECG essentially unchaged. Post-cath
   Tn 0.02 CK 88.  No anginal equivalent since admission to CCU.
   - Aspirin 325 po qd
   - Plavix 75 po qd
   - Atorvastatin 80 po qd
   .
   # HEMATOMA: Developed as pt began sundowning and became very
   anxious/restless ~2hrs s/p cath. Ultrasound was negative for hematoma,
   but induration and brusing along the inguinal ligament and suprapubic
   area developed afterwards. CT abd/pelvis showed 10x7cm pelvic fluid
   collection. Hematoma also possibly compressing R ureter causing
   hydronephrosis and possible calyceal rupture. Hct dropped from 31 two
   days PTA to 23.
   - Vascular on board
 no intervention indicated
   - Urology on board
 recommended conservative management at this point
   - Hct stable from last night
 will recheck H/H q12 to keep above [**8-24**]
 4UPRBC so far
   .
   # DELIRIUM: History of sundowning on previous hospital admissions.
   Given benzos last night and mental status deteriorated.  Pulled out
   some IVs and foley catheter. Will continue treating underlying
   conditions. Would stay away from benzos and use Haldol or Seroquel /
   Trazodone qpm. Use restraints as needed.
   - no recurrence overnight
   .
   # HYPERTENSION: On Atenolol at home. Hydralazine 10 IV previously
   required, none overnight.
   - Amlodipine 5 po qd
   - Carvedilol 6.25 po bid
   .
   # PUMP: No previous caths or echos. No history or symptoms of previous
   HF. Pt appears euvolemic. Echo showed mild diastolic dysfunction but
   EF>55%. Will hold off on fluid boluses
 got Lasix 80 prior to PRBC
   yesterday.
   - On Carvedilol 6.25 po bid
   - Will hold off on ACE/[**Last Name (un) **] given rising creatinine as outpatient ->
   will start when renal function improves
   .
   # CHRONIC KIDNEY INJURY: Baseline Cr 1yr ago was 1.3. Pt was advised to
   stop Olmesartan this past week over concerns of increased Cr to 2.0 two
   days PTA. Cr 1.7 on admission. GFR likely significantly low at baseline
   given age and small body habitus. FENa 3.3 so prerenal component is
   unlikely. SCr continues to rise slowly post-cath likely [**2-2**] dye load.
   - Hold nephrotoxins
   - Scr stable for past 24hrs
 will continue to monitor
   - Can d/c Foley
   .
   # HYPOTHYROIDISM: TSH wnl two days PTA. Continue levothyroxine 88mcg po
   qd.
   .
   # ANEMIA: Baseline outpatient H/H [**10-31**], MCV 93. Anemia of chronic
   disease on iron studies.
   - Will continue to monitor ongoing blood loss and keep H/H above [**8-24**]
   .
   FEN: heart healthy low sodium diet. Would add Zofran prn for nausea.
   .
   ACCESS: PIV's
   .
   CODE: Presumed full
   .
   COMM: patient, daughter is involved in care.
   .
   DISPO: Can call out to [**Hospital Ward Name 383**] 3, PT consult, OOB to chair

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 88-year-old female who underwent cardiac catheterization with a drug-eluting stent placement in the left main coronary artery extending to the left anterior descending (LAD) artery. She has a history of hypertension, chronic kidney injury, hypothyroidism, and Sjogren's syndrome.

The patient's current condition is characterized by:

1. Mild confusion and agitation, which is being managed with ranitidine and reorientation by staff.
2. Mild musculoskeletal back pain, which is not related to her anginal equivalent.
3. Mild lower abdominal pain and nausea, which are being managed with anti-nausea medication.
4. Hematuria and a pelvic hematoma, which is being managed conservatively.
5. Renal caliceal rupture, which is being monitored.
6. Chronic kidney injury, with a baseline creatinine of 1.3 and a current level of 3.1 mg/dL.
7. Hypothyroidism, which is being managed with levothyroxine 88 mcg po qd.
8. Anemia, which is being managed with blood transfusions and iron studies.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

1. Delirium: The patient's mild confusion and agitation can progress to delirium, which can lead to increased anxiety, agitation, and potential harm to the patient.
2. Hemorrhage: The patient's pelvic hematoma and renal caliceal rupture can lead to further bleeding and potential complications.
3. Chronic kidney injury: The patient's current creatinine level of 3.1 mg/dL can continue to rise, leading to potential kidney failure and dialysis.
4. Hypothyroidism: The patient's hypothyroidism can lead to further complications, such as decreased cardiac output, fatigue, and cognitive impairment.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia can lead to further complications, such as decreased oxygen delivery to tissues, fatigue, and potential cardiac complications.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Conservative management of the pelvic hematoma and renal caliceal rupture.
2. Continued monitoring of the patient's creatinine level and kidney function.
3. Management of the patient's hypothyroidism with levothyroxine 88 mcg po qd.
4. Management of the patient's anemia with blood transfusions and iron studies.
5. Monitoring of the patient's mental status and potential delirium.
6. Avoidance of nephrotoxins and continued monitoring of the patient's kidney function.
7. Holding off on fluid boluses and monitoring the patient's fluid status.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management to prevent potential complications and ensure optimal care.

   Assessment and Plan
   88yo F hx HTN, CKI, hypothyroidism, Sjogrens presented s/p cardiac cath
   with drug eluting stent to left main with extension to LAD now with
   pelvic hematoma and renal caliceal rupture.
   .
   # CORONARIES: Anginal equivalent is intrascapular back pain with
   nausea. Precath ECG showed ST elevations in V1-2 and AVR with
   depressions in 2,3,AVL. Left main disease seen on cath and stent placed
   to LMCA extending to LAD. Post-cath ECG essentially unchaged. Post-cath
   Tn 0.02 CK 88.  No anginal equivalent since admission to CCU.
   - Aspirin 325 po qd
   - Plavix 75 po qd
   - Atorvastatin 80 po qd
   .

   anxious/restless ~2hrs s/p cath. Ultrasound was negative for hematoma,
   but induration and brusing along the inguinal ligament and suprapubic
   area developed afterwards. CT abd/pelvis showed 10x7cm pelvic fluid
   collection. Hematoma also possibly compressing R ureter causing
   hydronephrosis and possible calyceal rupture. Hct dropped from 31 two
   days PTA to 23.
   - Vascular on board
 no intervention indicated
   - Urology on board
 recommended conservative management at this point
   - Hct stable from last night
 will recheck H/H q12 to keep above [**8-24**]
 4UPRBC so far
   .
   # DELIRIUM: History of sundowning on previous hospital admissions.
   Given benzos last night and mental status deteriorated.  Pulled out
   some IVs and foley catheter. Will continue treating underlying
   conditions. Would stay away from benzos and use Haldol or Seroquel /
   Trazodone qpm. Use restraints as needed.
   - no recurrence overnight
   .
   # HYPERTENSION: On Atenolol at home. Hydralazine 10 IV previously
   required, none overnight.
   - Amlodipine 5 po qd
   - Carvedilol 6.25 po bid
   .
   # PUMP: No previous caths or echos. No history or symptoms of previous
   HF. Pt appears euvolemic. Echo showed mild diastolic dysfunction but
   EF>55%. Will hold off on fluid boluses
 got Lasix 80 prior to PRBC
   yesterday.
   - On Carvedilol 6.25 po bid
   - Will hold off on ACE/[**Last Name (un) **] given rising creatinine as outpatient ->
   will start when renal function improves
   .
   # CHRONIC KIDNEY INJURY: Baseline Cr 1yr ago was 1.3. Pt was advised to
   stop Olmesartan this past week over concerns of increased Cr to 2.0 two
   days PTA. Cr 1.7 on admission. GFR likely significantly low at baseline
   given age and small body habitus. FENa 3.3 so prerenal component is
   unlikely. SCr continues to rise slowly post-cath likely [**2-2**] dye load.
   - Hold nephrotoxins
   - Scr stable for past 24hrs
 will continue to monitor
   - Can d/c Foley
   .
   # HYPOTHYROIDISM: TSH wnl two days PTA. Continue levothyroxine 88mcg po
   qd.
   .
   # ANEMIA: Baseline outpatient H/H [**10-31**], MCV 93. Anemia of chronic
   disease on iron studies.
   - Will continue to monitor ongoing blood loss and keep H/H above [**8-24**]
   .
   FEN: heart healthy low sodium diet. Would add Zofran prn for nausea.
   .
   ACCESS: PIV's
   .
   CODE: Presumed full
   .
   COMM: patient, daughter is involved in care.
   .

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 88-year-old female who underwent cardiac catheterization with a drug-eluting stent placed to the left main coronary artery extending to the left anterior descending artery. She developed a pelvic hematoma and renal caliceal rupture post-catheterization.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: T 37.6°C, HR 67 bpm, BP 119/61 mmHg, RR 21 inspirations per minute, SpO2 96%
* Physical examination: Well-nourished, no acute distress, anxious
* Lab results:
	+ Hct: 32.5%
	+ WBC: 10.6
	+ Cr: 3.1 mg/dL
	+ TropT: 0.02
	+ Glucose: 212 mg/dL
	+ Other labs: CK/CKMB/Troponin-T: 88/0.02, Differential-Neuts: 89.6%, Lymph: 6.9%, Mono: 3.2%, Eos: 0.1%, Ca++: 8.3 mg/dL, Mg++: 3.0 mg/dL, PO4: 4.6 mg/dL

Potential medical complications that can arise based on the patient's condition include:

1. Hemorrhagic shock: The patient's pelvic hematoma and renal caliceal rupture can lead to significant blood loss, potentially causing hemorrhagic shock.
2. Acute kidney injury: The patient's rising creatinine levels and history of chronic kidney injury may indicate acute kidney injury, which can worsen if not managed promptly.
3. Delirium: The patient's history of sundowning and recent use of benzodiazepines may increase the risk of delirium, which can be challenging to manage in the ICU setting.
4. Hypothyroidism: The patient's history of hypothyroidism may require close monitoring and adjustment of thyroid hormone replacement therapy.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia of chronic disease may require ongoing management, particularly in the context of ongoing blood loss.
6. Infection: The patient's indwelling catheters and recent surgical procedure may increase the risk of infection, which can be challenging to diagnose and treat in the ICU setting.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Vascular consult: No intervention indicated
* Urology consult: Recommended conservative management
* Fluid management: Holding off on fluid boluses and monitoring for signs of hypovolemia
* Nephrotoxins: Holding off on nephrotoxins until renal function improves
* Foley catheter: Can be discontinued if Hct remains stable
* Delirium management: Continuing to treat underlying conditions and using alternative sedatives as needed
* Hypothyroidism management: Continuing levothyroxine therapy
* Anemia management: Monitoring ongoing blood loss and keeping H/H above 8-24
* Infection prevention: Monitoring for signs of infection and taking precautions to prevent catheter-related infections

   Assessment and Plan
   88yo F hx HTN, CKI, hypothyroidism, Sjogrens presented s/p cardiac cath
   with drug eluting stent to left main with extension to LAD now with
   pelvic hematoma and renal caliceal rupture.
   .
   # CORONARIES: Anginal equivalent is intrascapular back pain with
   nausea. Precath ECG showed 1mm ST elevations in V1-2 and AVR with
   depressions in 2,3,AVL. Left main disease seen on cath and stent placed
   to LMCA extending to LAD. Post-cath ECG essentially unchaged. Post-cath
   Tn 0.02 CK 88.  No anginal equivalent since admission to CCU.
   - Aspirin 325 po qd
   - Plavix 75 po qd
   - Atorvastatin 80 po qd
   .
   # HEMATOMA: Developed as pt began sundowning and became very
   anxious/restless ~2hrs s/p cath. Ultrasound was negative for hematoma,
   but induration and brusing along the inguinal ligament and suprapubic
   area developed afterwards. CT abd/pelvis showed 10x7cm pelvic fluid
   collection. Hematoma also possibly compressing R ureter causing
   hydronephrosis and possible calyceal rupture. Hct dropped from 31 two
   days PTA to 23.  Pt received 4uPRBC and Hct has increased and
   stabilized.
   - Vascular on board
 no intervention indicated
   - Urology on board
 recommended MAG3 Renal scan to evaluate function
   of non-obstructed kidney
   - Hct stable
 will f/u H/H q24
   .
   # ACUTE ON CHRONIC KIDNEY INJURY: Baseline Cr 1yr ago was 1.3. Pt was
   advised to stop Olmesartan this past week over concerns of increased Cr
   to 2.0 two days PTA. Cr 1.7 on admission. FENa 3.3 so prerenal
   component is unlikely. Cr increased since admission likely [**2-2**]
   obstruction of right kidney & dye load. Cr currently trending down.
   - Hold nephrotoxins
   .
   # DELIRIUM: History of sundowning on previous hospital admissions.
   Given benzos on day of admission and mental status deteriorated.
   Pulled out some IVs and foley catheter. Will continue treating
   underlying conditions. Would stay away from benzos and use Haldol or
   Seroquel / Trazodone qpm. Use restraints as needed.
   - No recurrence overnight
   .
   # PUMP: No previous caths or echos. No history or symptoms of previous
   HF. Pt appears euvolemic. Echo showed mild diastolic dysfunction but
   EF>55%. Will hold off on fluid boluses and give Lasix prior to future
   PRBC.
   - On Carvedilol 6.25 po bid
   - Will hold off on ACE/[**Last Name (un) **] given rising creatinine as outpatient
 will
   start when renal function improves
   .
   # HYPERTENSION: On Atenolol at home.
   - Amlodipine 5 po qd
   - Carvedilol 6.25 po bid
   .
   # HYPOTHYROIDISM: TSH wnl two days PTA. Continue levothyroxine 88mcg po
   qd.
   .
   # ANEMIA: Baseline outpatient H/H [**10-31**], MCV 93. Anemia of chronic
   disease on iron studies.
   - Will continue to monitor ongoing blood loss and keep H/H above [**8-24**]
   .
   FEN: heart healthy low sodium diet. Would add Zofran prn for nausea.
   .
   ACCESS: PIV's
   .
   CODE: Presumed full
   .
   COMM: patient, daughter is involved in care.
   .
